awd_titl_txt: From Molecular Simplicity to Supramolecular Complexity: Low Symmetry Packings of Ionic Spherical Micelles
awd_abstract_narration:
Surfactants are small molecules in which a water-soluble headgroup is attached to an insoluble tail.  Common examples of useful surfactants are soaps and detergents.  As a result of the different solubilities of the headgroup and the tail, surfactants spontaneously form ordered assemblies in water.  The assemblies can range from very simple spheres dispersed in water to much more sophisticated geometries.  However, predicting the geometry of a complex assembly from the chemical structure of the surfactant remains a significant challenge.  Motivated by the desire to control surfactant assembly and access complex structures with unusual and useful properties, Prof. Mahesh Mahanthappa and his research team at the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities seek to understand how surfactant structure dictates the packing geometry and the stability of an assembly.  Their discoveries could have broad implications for the future design and development of surfactants for applications such as enhanced oil recovery, personal care product formulation, drug encapsulation, and therapeutic delivery.  The project also contributes to the interdisciplinary research training of undergraduate and graduate students, including members of underrepresented groups.  Public outreach demonstrations using visually appealing soap bubble froths showcase the properties of surfactants and help to arouse the interest of students in science.

A delicate balance of non-covalent interactions drives the supramolecular assembly of minimally hydrated amphiphiles into different lyotrophic liquid-crystalline phases.  Of particular interest is the complex Frank-Kasper (FK) phases, which apparently arise from a frustrated non-covalent force balance that minimizes local variations in amphiphile solvation, while maximizing global micelle cohesion across the supramolecular assembly.  Specific experiments of this project aim to 1) understand how the ionic amphiphile tail structure, counterion symmetry, and chirality impact micellar aggregation and consequent packing of the micelles into high coordination number, low symmetry lattices; 2) evaluate whether these complex packings are long-lived metastable states or thermodynamic equilibrium phases; and 3) assess whether non-ionic amphiphiles might form these complex phases.  An important goal is to uncover new molecular design criteria that drive the formation of lyotropic liquid crystals with exceptional translational order, at length scales far exceeding those of their constituent molecular and supramolecular micelle building blocks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

     "Soaps" are molecular amphiphiles comprising a water-soluble "hydrophilic" headgroup linked to a water-insoluble "hydrophobic" tail. Amphiphiles aggregate in water to form nanometer-sized particles called micelles, in which the hydrophobic tails are hidden in the particle interior and the hydrophilic headgroups line the exterior surface. To minimize unfavorable water/hydrophobic contacts, micelles form spheres that minimize the particle surface area to volume ratio. Concentrating dilute micelle solutions drives these soft particles to pack into lyotropic liquid crystals (LLCs). Intuitively, one expects these spherical micelles to form close-packed crystals akin to the stacks of oranges in a grocery. 

     Recently, privileged ionic amphiphiles were shown to form complex micellar LLCs known as Frank-Kasper (FK) phases. FK LLCs emerge from optimization of interparticle electrostatic cohesion in the micelle ensemble, while minimizing deviations in the spherical character of the micelles. The lack of robust amphiphile designs for accessing FK LLCs motivated these fundamental self-assembly studies toward the ultimate goal of assembling new, complex LLCs with unusual and useful properties. Development of robust approaches for FK LLC self-assembly offers opportunities to produce new mesoporous materials for catalysis and chemoselective separations, and new carriers for therapeutic drug delivery. 

     This project identified mechanisms for FK LLC formation by minimally hydrated amphiphile self-assembly. One research direction showed how ionic amphiphile tail and counterion structures direct the ordered packings of spherical micelles. Another research thrust identified conditions for guiding commercially useful, nonionic amphiphiles to form FK LLC sphere packings. Thus, these studies revealed new insights into amphiphile designs that foster the formation of complex micelle packings, which may enable chemists, physicists, and engineers to exploit their unique properties in future applications.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project used a combination of synthetic chemistry and materials characterization methods to uncover (non)ionic small molecule amphiphile designs that direct the formation of complex micellar LLCs in water. These studies revealed how ionic amphiphile tail and organic counterion structures exert control over the preferred micelle sizes and dispersities, which can either frustrate or foster FK LLC formation. Additional studies demonstrated the subtle interplay of self-assembly thermodynamics and LLC phase nucleation and growth that dictate the observed supramolecular assembly structure. For example, the application of specific thermal processing protocols to LLC compositions of certain nonionic amphiphiles unexpectedly yielded previously unrecognized FK σ phases as long-lived metastable states that persist for nearly 5 months. However, mechanically shearing these metastable LLCs accelerates their transformation into the thermodynamic equilibrium state in a matter of minutes. Studies of the co-assembly of a dianionic amphiphile, a hydrocarbon oil, and water serendipitously yielded the first instance of a lyotropic dodecagonal quasicrystal (LDDQC) of oil-swollen micelles, which exhibits local 12-fold rotational symmetry with no long-range translational order. This LDDQC is a long-lived metastable structure that ultimately transforms into a FK σ phase over ≥ 30 months. These observations crucially defy the conventional wisdom that molecular rearrangements to achieve thermodynamic equilibrium states in supramolecular assemblies of low molecular weight compounds are fast. This straightforward method for preparing LDDQCs offers opportunities to probe the structures, dynamics, and properties of these "exotic" materials, which exhibit properties intermediate between those of periodic crystals and amorphous (glassy) solids. Finally, synergistic studies of block copolymer self-assembly into FK phases have revealed initial glimpses into lengthscale-invariant self-assembly principles that guide FK phase formation in chemically disparate systems. Research findings have been disseminated to academic and industrial scientists through four (4) invited academic department colloquia, five (5) invited and six (6) contributed oral presentations at international scientific meetings, five (5) presentations at industrial research centers of commodity amphiphile producers, as well as ten (10) peer-reviewed journal publications.

Broader Impacts

    This project has significantly impacted the training of five (5) graduate students (including one under-represented minority and two women), one (1) postdoctoral research associate, and two (2) undergraduates (including one woman) in collaborative research in organic materials chemistry at the nexus of chemistry, chemical engineering, and materials science, thereby enhancing American competitiveness in chemistry. Notably, four (4) project personnel are now industrial or national laboratory research scientists, and one (1) former undergraduate researcher is now pursuing a Ph.D. in chemical engineering. Project personnel also extensively developed skills for communicating both the scientific and practical goals of their work to technical and non-technical audiences in both written and verbal forms, including peer-reviewed journal publications and international conference presentations. Project personnel also worked to broaden participation of traditionally under-represented students in science, technology, and mathematics (STEM) professions through their participation in a program that brings interactive science demonstrations to under-served middle school students in communities throughout Minneapolis and St. Paul.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2022
Modified by: Mahesh K Mahanthappa

Project Outcomes

     "Soaps" are molecular amphiphiles comprising a water-soluble "hydrophilic" headgroup linked to a water-insoluble "hydrophobic" tail. Amphiphiles aggregate in water to form nanometer-sized particles called micelles, in which the hydrophobic tails are hidden in the particle interior and the hydrophilic headgroups line the exterior surface. To minimize unfavorable water/hydrophobic contacts, micelles form spheres that minimize the particle surface area to volume ratio. Concentrating dilute micelle solutions drives these soft particles to pack into lyotropic liquid crystals (LLCs). Intuitively, one expects these spherical micelles to form close-packed crystals akin to the stacks of oranges in a grocery.

Development of robust approaches for FK LLC self-assembly offers opportunities to produce new mesoporous materials for catalysis and chemoselective separations, and new carriers for therapeutic drug delivery.

One research direction showed how ionic amphiphile tail and counterion structures direct the ordered packings of spherical micelles. Another research thrust identified conditions for guiding commercially useful, nonionic amphiphiles to form FK LLC sphere packings. Intellectual Merit:

This project used a combination of synthetic chemistry and materials characterization methods to uncover (non)ionic small molecule amphiphile designs that direct the formation of complex micellar LLCs in water. Additional studies demonstrated the subtle interplay of self-assembly thermodynamics and LLC phase nucleation and growth that dictate the observed supramolecular assembly structure. For example, the application of specific thermal processing protocols to LLC compositions of certain nonionic amphiphiles unexpectedly yielded previously unrecognized FK σ phases as long-lived metastable states that persist for nearly 5 months. However, mechanically shearing these metastable LLCs accelerates their transformation into the thermodynamic equilibrium state in a matter of minutes. Studies of the co-assembly of a dianionic amphiphile, a hydrocarbon oil, and water serendipitously yielded the first instance of a lyotropic dodecagonal quasicrystal (LDDQC) of oil-swollen micelles, which exhibits local 12-fold rotational symmetry with no long-range translational order. This straightforward method for preparing LDDQCs offers opportunities to probe the structures, dynamics, and properties of these "exotic" materials, which exhibit properties intermediate between those of periodic crystals and amorphous (glassy) solids. Finally, synergistic studies of block copolymer self-assembly into FK phases have revealed initial glimpses into lengthscale-invariant self-assembly principles that guide FK phase formation in chemically disparate systems. Research findings have been disseminated to academic and industrial scientists through four (4) invited academic department colloquia, five (5) invited and six (6) contributed oral presentations at international scientific meetings, five (5) presentations at industrial research centers of commodity amphiphile producers, as well as ten (10) peer-reviewed journal publications.

Broader Impacts

    This project has significantly impacted the training of five (5) graduate students (including one under-represented minority and two women), one (1) postdoctoral research associate, and two (2) undergraduates (including one woman) in collaborative research in organic materials chemistry at the nexus of chemistry, chemical engineering, and materials science, thereby enhancing American competitiveness in chemistry. Notably, four (4) project personnel are now industrial or national laboratory research scientists, and one (1) former undergraduate researcher is now pursuing a Ph.D. in chemical engineering. Project personnel also extensively developed skills for communicating both the scientific and practical goals of their work to technical and non-technical audiences in both written and verbal forms, including peer-reviewed journal publications and international conference presentations. Project personnel also worked to broaden participation of traditionally under-represented students in science, technology, and mathematics (STEM) professions through their participation in a program that brings interactive science demonstrations to under-served middle school students in communities throughout Minneapolis and St. Paul.
